sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Bacteria’s antibiotic resistance is one of the major challenges in the treatment of infectious diseases.
With increasing difficulty in discovering antibiotics, there is urgent need to develop antibiotic-free
therapeutic strategies to address this grand challenge. In this report, we developed a polypyrrole (PPy)-
based photothermal nanoantibiotic (PTNA) for effective treatment of multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacterial
infection. PTNA was fabricated by polymerizing pyrrole onto anionic vesicle to integrate the cationic and
photothermal properties of PPy for combinatory killing against bacteria. PTNA exhibits strong
photothermal effect in the NIR-II (1064 nm) biowindow, thus is feasible for in vivo therapy due to deeper
tissue penetration. Our in vitro experiments revealed that PTNA can significantly inhibit the growth of
MDR bacteria (S. Typhimurium), alleviate inflammatory response of infected cells, and prevent biofilm
formation. More importantly, PTNA showed significant therapeutic effect in S. Typhimurium-infected
animal disease model of acute systemic infection by inhibiting bacterial growth, lowering inflammatory
responses and pathological changes, and eventually improving the survival rate of mice. Finally, PTNA
had safe profiles in vitro and in vivo with no visible toxicity detected. Therefore, we believe PTNA may
serve as a promising antibiotic-free antimicrobial material for the effective treatment of MDR bacterial
infection.
Keywords: Photothermal therapy, NIR-II window, polypyrrole, antibiotic-free antimicrobial material,
multidrug-resistant bacterial infection

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), bacterial infection has become a major threat to global public health, which caused the highest death rate in developing countries in the past decade.1 Antibiotics have been the most effective treatment against bacterial diseases.2 However, the long-term
abuse use of antibiotics has promoted bacterial evolution with resistance against a wide variety of antibiotics, threatening public health via numerous paths including food, water, and livestock.3 A global
report by WHO suggested that antibiotic-resistant bacteria are responsible for nearly 700,000 death annually, which is predicted to be 10 million by 2050.4 Therefore, there is a urgent need to address the
antibiotic resistance crisis worldwide. Discovery of new antibiotics may represent a conventional and yet temporarily effective strategy against multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacteria.5, 6 Nevertheless, there is a
trend of decrease in appearance of new antibiotics in the market given the increasing challenge of
antibiotic discovery.
Developing antibiotic-free strategies against bacterial infection is a promising approach to circumvent
this dilemma. Notably, antibacterial nanomaterials have gained remarkable success in killing bacteria, showing great potential to revolutionize antibiotic-free strategies.7 Among which, nanomaterials of
photothermal effect under irradiation of near infrared light (NIR, 650-1350 nm) have drawn great attention for fighting bacterial infection due to its effectiveness against MDR bacteria and its safe profile.8, 9 The majority of reported photothermal nanomaterials including carbon-based nanocomposites,10 noble metallic nanomaterials,11 and polymeric nanomaterials12-15 are generally responsive to laser irradiation
within the NIR-I window (650-950 nm), exhibiting relatively short tissue-penetration depth for in vivo use.16 Thus, it is highly desired to develop effective antibacterial photothermal nanomaterials in the NIRII window (1000-1350 nm), especially for treating deep-tissue bacterial infection.17, 18 To date,
photothermal nanomaterials that work in the NIR-II window are generally inorganic nanosystems (e.g. gold nanostructures,19-21 MXene,22 carbon-based nanomaterials23), which hold limited clinical translation potential comparing to organic nanomaterials.24, 25 Some studies demonstrated the antibacterial activity

of polypyrrole and polyaniline nanocomposite on cotton fabric26-29. Polypyrrole (PPy) is a conductive
polymer that capable of absorbing light in the NIR range, which has been widely employed as
photoabsorbing agent within a variety of nanosystems for photothermal therapy of cancer, duo to stable photothermal properties and good biocompatibility,30-34 but mainly in the NIR-I window.35-37 Herein, we
employed a facile synthesis method for the oxidative polymerization of pyrrole by enzyme Trametes
versicolor laccase (TvL) in aqueous solution in the presence of anionic vesicles formed from sodium bis-(2-ethylhexyl) sulfosuccinate (AOT).38 The AOT-templated PPy exhibits strong light absorption at
1000 nm, suggesting it can work in the NIR-II window. Furthermore, reports have revealed the antimicrobial ability of PPy due to its cationic nature.29, 39, 40 Herein, we combined the photothermal and
antimicrobial capabilities of PPy into one nanosystem to form a photothermal nanoantibiotic (PTNA). We selected MDR bacterial (S. Typhimurium) to establish a model of acute systemic infection in mice.41
Our studies revealed that PTNA can serve as a promising NIR-II photothermal antibiotic material for
effective treatment of MDR bacterial infection both in vitro and in vivo (Figure 1), thus hold great
application potentials.

2.1 Synthesis and characterization of PTNA. The oxidative polymerization of pyrrole was conducted

by the enzyme Trametes versicolor laccase (TvL) and dioxygen (O2) in aqueous solution at pH 3.5 in the presence of AOT, following a protocol reported by Walde et al.38 During polymerization, cationic PPy
were adsorbed onto the membrane of AOT due to electrostatic interactions forming PTNA, which are
stable and well-dispersed in various buffers. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images showed
that AOT remained intact after the polymerization of PPy on its membrane (Figure 2a). Dynamic light
scattering (DLS) revealed a slight increase in size and a significant increase in zeta-potential, suggesting
the formation of PTNA (Figure 2b). PTNA exhibited potent stability in various physiological buffers such
as phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, pH 7) and cell culture medium (Figure S1).
2.2 Photothermal properties of PTNA in the NIR-II window. PTNA exhibited a broad and intense light
absorption ranging from the visible to the NIR region covering both NIR-I and NIR-II windows with
maximum absorption at ~450 nm and ~1000 nm (Figure 2c, Figure S2). In contrast, adsorption of pyrrole
on AOT without polymerization yielded minimal absorbance in the NIR range, suggesting the intense
light absorption capability of PTNA was derived from PPy. We next examined the photothermal
conversion properties of PTNA in various PPy concentrations (5, 10, 20, and 40 μg/mL), which were exposed to continuous-wave laser irradiation at 1064 nm with power of 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 W/cm2, at pH
3.5 or pH 7. PTNA showed a strong laser-power-dependent photothermal conversion effect (Figure 2d,
Figure S3), with ambient temperature elevated by >40 °C after continuous irradiation for 600 s at power of 1 W/cm2 or above. As reported previously, the in vivo maximum permissible exposure (MPE) for NIR-II light is 1 W/cm2, therefore a laser power of 1 W/cm2 was used for subsequent in vitro and in vivo experiments.18 Similar heating curve was observed with PTNA dispersed in the original reaction buffer
(pH 3.5) or in PBS buffer (pH 7). PTNA exhibited potent photothermal robustness after multicycles of
on-off laser irradiation (Figure 2e). Photothermal conversion of PTNA with laser penetrated through a
piece of mouse tissue to mimic in vivo conditions was investigated (Figure 2f), with temperature elevated
by ~20 °C after 600 s of irradiation, suggesting PTNA may serve as an effective photothermal agent in
vivo. Photothermal properties of PTNA at pH3.5 were measured by the photothermal conversion efficiency
(η), which was calculated using ; η = [hS(Tmax- Tsurr)-Q0] / [ I (1 – 10-A)] , 51.59%. Since polypyrrole is relatively stable in acidic solutions, but dedoping tends to happen in neutral conditions (pH7) due to

Lastly, in vivo safety test was conducted in mice. PTNA was intragastrically administered at a dosage
of 0.4 mg/kg, following laser irradiation at 1064 nm for 600 seconds. Histopathological staining of major
organs and tissues suggested no observable toxicity after photothermal treatment of PTNA (Figure 3d).
Overall, these results suggested that PTNA has safe in vitro and in vivo profiles and may be further
pursued for treating bacterial infection.
2.4 In vitro antibacterial activities of PTNA against MDR bacteria. S. Typhimurium is a zoonotic
pathogen and one of the most highly isolated bacteria at present that causes severe gastroenteritis in
human and systemic infection in mice, which is listed at the top of the bacterial food poisoning incidence in the world.43 WHO has expressed serious concern regarding the development of multidrug resistance
of S. Typhimurium. Drug sensitivity test indicated that S. Typhimurium (strain DT104) is resistant to a
wide variety of antibiotics including ampicillin, kanamycin, oxacillin, doxycycline, tobramycin, amikacin,
florfenicol, gentamycin, and tetracycline (Figure S5).
The antibacterial effect of PTNA against S. Typhimurium was examined (Figure 4). 1.0×109 CFU/mL of
S. Typhimurium was cultured with PTNA (40 μg/mL) along with other control treatments for 1 hour. Comparing to the groups treated with PBS and Laser only (1064 nm, 1 W/cm2, 10 min), significant
reduction of viable bacteria was observed for PTNA and PTNA/Laser (PTNA-L) treatments (Figure 4a). Bacteria treated with PTNA alone had a reduction of 2 log10(CFU/mL), indicating that PTNA has certain
antimicrobial property. But with laser irradiation, PTNA can reduce the viability of bacteria by 6 log10(CFU/mL), suggesting the elevated temperature induced by its photothermal effect can significantly
strengthen the antibiotic performance of PTNA. The bacteria enter the logarithmic growth phase as the culture time increases, but PTNA-L treatment can still reduce its growth by ~4 log10(CFU/mL) (Figure
S6). In contrast, PBS, AOT, or laser irradiation had no inhibitive effect on bacteria growth, suggesting
the antibacterial effect was derived from PTNA (Figure S7). The antibacterial property of PTNA was

further examined on LB agar plates as shown in Figure 4b. A significant reduction in bacterial colonies
was achieved by treating bacteria with PTNA-L. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images showed
no apparent morphological changes for bacteria treated with PBS, PTNA only, or laser irradiation only,
with them exhibiting a rod-like shape of smooth cell walls (Figure 4c). Nevertheless, bacteria treated
with PTNA-L suffered from pronounced membrane damage, a sign of dead or dying bacteria. The viability of S. typhimurium was further determined by staining bacteria with SYTOTM9 and propidium
iodide (PI) to distinguish live and dead cells (Figure 4d). In good agreement to above results, PTNA-L
treatment nearly killed all the bacteria, while PTNA or laser irradiation separately had very mild
antibacterial effect. With the deformation and rupture of bacteria, mixtures of cellular components (e.g.
proteins and nucleic acids) may be released to accumulate around bacteria forming biofilms to resist antimicrobial treatments.44
To study whether photothermal treatment of bacteria is capable of prohibiting biofilm formation, we
quantified the biofilm mass using the crystal violet staining assay (Figure 4e). Except for PBS, treatments
of PTNA, Laser, and PTNA-L all induced a reduction in the formation of biofilm, with PTNA-L having the
highest reduction effect. Taken together, these results unambiguously proved that photothermal effect
of PTNA in the NIR-II window can significantly inhibit MDR bacteria growth in vitro.
2.5 Alleviated inflammation in vitro. After bacterial infection, inflammatory response is the major cause for severe organ failure and death of the host.45 In S. Typhimurium-infection, signals transmitted
through ERK kinases are known to induce the expression of proinflammatory genes such as IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-α.46 The previous study found that high levels of proinflammatory genes expression favored repeated infections in mice47-49 and was the causes of severe systemic inflammation.50, 51 Besides,
several past studies have demonstrated that the host inflammatory response facilitated S. Typhimurium
growth.52 Here we examined whether the photothermal treatment by PTNA can alleviate bacterial
infection-induced cellular inflammation in vitro. NCM460 cells were infected with S. typhimurium and
cultured with various treatments. The expression of inflammatory factors IL6, IL-8, and TNF-α by the
infected cells were measured and calculated against normal cells without infection (Figure 5a). PTNA-

day-5 for measuring production of cytokines (IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-α). A number of 2 mice from each
group were randomly chosen and sacrificed on day-3 and day-5 to collect major organs and tissues for
measuring cytokine levels and for histopathological examinations. Feces were collected on a daily basis
to measure the level of fecal calprotectin, which is a known acute inflammatory marker. Previous
research had shown that calprotectin was highly induced in the fecal samples of mice infected with S. Typhimurium58, 59 and calprotectin enhances the competitive advantage of S. Typhimurium.60
Measurements of cytokines in serum and major organ/tissues collected on day-3 and day-5 revealed
that mice treated with PTNA and PTNA-L had significantly alleviated expression of IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-α,
with PTNA-L having the highest inhibitive effect on cytokine production (Figure 6b,c, Figure S10-13).
Fecal calprotectin measurements showed similar results (Figure 6d). Same to in vitro cellular studies,
we examined the activities of pERK/MAPK signaling pathway in major organs/tissues by western blotting
(Figure 6e, Figure S14). S. Typhimurium-infection led to apparent systemic activation of pERK/MAPK
signaling pathway in various tissues examined, which was significantly attenuated by treatments of
PTNA and PTNA-L. In conclusion, PTNA-based photothermal treatment can significantly alleviate the
activation of p-ERK/MAPK signaling pathway in S. typhimurium-infected mice and attenuate the
production of inflammatory factors thus lower the risk of systemic acute inflammatory response
syndrome post infection and eventually improve the survival rate of mice.
2.7 Histopathological examinations. The lesions in major organs/tissues on third- and fifth-day post-
infection was illustrated (Figure 7, Figure S15 and S16). In the normal group of no bacterial infection,
there is no apparent pathological change in tissue sections. In contrast, severe pathological changes
were observed in major tissues of bacteria-infected mice if no effective antibacterial treatments were
given, such as mice treated with PBS or laser irradiation. Observed pathological changes include
mucosal erosion in cecum and duodenum; multifocal hepatocellular necrosis, hepatic sinusal
inflammatory cell infiltration and bacteria infiltration in liver; multifocal marked necrosis, moderate
hemorrhage, marked perivascular and alveolar septum inflammatory cell infiltration in lung; necrosis,

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text:
We have developed a combinatory antibacterial strategy to treat MDR bacterial infection, by integrating
the antimicrobial and photothermal properties of PPy into PTNA. PTNA exhibited strong absorbance in
the NIR-II biowindow thus hold great in vivo application potentials. We conducted comprehensive in vitro
and in vivo experiments to demonstrate that photothermal therapy by PTNA can significantly inhibit the
growth of MDR S. typhimurium, reduce inflammatory responses, alleviate pathological changes, and
eventually increase the survival rate of bacteria-infected mice. We believe PTNA can serve as a
universal photothermal antimicrobial platform to effectively kill a wide variety of MDR bacteria strains.
Therefore, it holds great clinical translational potential towards various MDR bacterial infection diseases.

The BALB/c mice (4-6 weeks old) were dosed by 0.4 mg/ml PTNA and under 1064 nm NIR laser (1 W/cm2, 10 min) once a day for three days. The cytotoxicity was detected by H&E staining of heart, liver, spleen, lung, kidney, duodenum, colon and cecum. Antibacterial effect of PTNA. The antibacterial activity of PTNA was determined through the number of colony-forming units (CFUs) using the plate-counting method. Four groups were tested: (I) bacteria; (II) bacteria + PTNA; (III) bacteria + laser; and (IV) bacteria + PTNA + laser. The final concentration of PTNA was 40 μg/mL and the bacteria was 1.0 ×109 CFU/mL. After incubation with PTNA for 30 min, 1 h, 2 h, 4 h and 8 h, the mixture was exposed to 1064 nm laser for 10 min at 1.0 W/cm2, the bacterial dispersions were diluted to 1.0 ×104 CFU/mL and spread on agar culture plates to culture at 37°C for another 15 h. At last, the bacteria were visualized with confocal fluorescence microscope. Anti-biofilm experiments. Add 100 μl of culture solution to each well of 96-well polystyrene microplate, inoculate 10 μl of overnight culture solution, and incubate at 37°C for 36 h to obtain biofilm. The destruction of bacteria biofilms were measured as follows: the biofilms were first incubated with 40 μg/mL PTNA for 2 h in LB medium and then the PTNA + laser group was exposed to the 1064 nm laser at 1.0 W/cm2 for 10 min/well. The intestinal injury was scored for mucosal erosion, mucosal regenerative hyperplasia and
lymphangiectasia. A score scaled at 0 to 4 represents the severity: 0 for no inflammation, 1 for modest
numbers of infiltrating cells, 2 for mild mucosal hyperplasia, 3 for massive infiltration with inflammatory
cells accompanied by disrupted mucosal architecture and marked mucosal hyperplasia, and 4 for all of the above plus61.
The liver injury was scored for necrosis, inflammatory cell infiltration and hepatocellular vacuolation. A
score scaled at 0 to 4 represents the severity: 0 for no or minimal, 1 for mild, 2 for moderate, 3 for marked, and 4 for severe62.
The lung injury was scored for edema, neutrophil infiltration, hemorrhage, and necrosis. A score scaled
at 0 to 4 represents the severity: 0 for no or very minor, 1 for modest and limited, 2 for intermediate, 3 for widespread or prominent, and 4 for widespread and most prominent63.
The spleen injury was scored for necrosis, inflammatory cell infiltration and white pulp decreased
lymphocyte. A score scaled at 0 to 4 represents the severity: 0 for no or minimal, 1 for mild, 2 for moderate, 3 for marked, and 4 for severe64.
Statistical analysis. All the results were presented from at least three independent experiments.

metadata.abstractText: Bacteria’s antibiotic resistance is one of the major challenges in the treatment of infectious diseases. With increasing difficulty in discovering antibiotics, there is urgent need to develop antibiotic-free therapeutic strategies to address this grand challenge. In this report, we developed a polypyrrole (PPy)based photothermal nanoantibiotic (PTNA) for effective treatment of multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacterial infection. PTNA was fabricated by polymerizing pyrrole onto anionic vesicle to integrate the cationic and photothermal properties of PPy for combinatory killing against bacteria. PTNA exhibits strong photothermal effect in the NIR-II (1064 nm) biowindow, thus is feasible for in vivo therapy due to deeper tissue penetration. Our in vitro experiments revealed that PTNA can significantly inhibit the growth of MDR bacteria (S. Typhimurium), alleviate inflammatory response of infected cells, and prevent biofilm formation. More importantly, PTNA showed significant therapeutic effect in S. Typhimurium-infected animal disease model of acute systemic infection by inhibiting bacterial growth, lowering inflammatory responses and pathological changes, and eventually improving the survival rate of mice. Finally, PTNA had safe profiles in vitro and in vivo with no visible toxicity detected. Therefore, we believe PTNA may serve as a promising antibiotic-free antimicrobial material for the effective treatment of MDR bacterial
